values:
I turned 45 last week, which is fine.  Trout took me mountain biking up at Winding Stairs Gap.  While I'll never be a professional, I'm did okay.  I made it up the uphills better than in the past and didn't feel like I was holding him up too much.  My legs were killing me though by the time we made it to pavement.  I felt good!  

Trout gave me a pedicure and manicure as a present.  Neither of which I had ever experienced before.  I have developed what I call old lady feet, so I was excited about the pedicure.  I made the appointment and drove up the mountain to Highlands.  In my excitement, I arrived too early and was killing time sitting in my car and listening to some Michael Franti when a group of preschoolers, all holding a rope, walked by.  One little bastard pointed at me and begin singing his own little song of "Old grandma sitting in her car...Old grandma sitting in her car."  The moment was so surreal I thought I had fallen into a Vonnegut short story.  I refrained from getting out of my car and pounding the little shit into a gooey pile of preschooler snot.  I sat there and wondered if all the women before me had such a defining moment of age.  Then I decided what the hell, it'll make a funny story, and I don't feel old.  

My pedicure was wonderful and my old lady feet are gone!

I love Beowulf, and, damn it, my students love it, too.


take the WHAT BAD BOOK ARE YOU test.
and go to mewing.net. not as good as reading a good book, but way better than a bad one.

The last time I did a quizilla I found out that I'm Kip (and here I thought I was LaFawnduh). This is much more accurate!
""Which cocktail are you?""

You're a Rusty Nail!! A smooth, short blend of scotch whiskey and drambuie. You're seriously cool and you love guitars, cars and the bluuuuuees, man!!
Take this quiz!

Quizilla | Join | Make A Quiz | More Quizzes | Grab Code

Trout won a new bike from REI on the Cycle North Carolina ride this year.  He decided to give the bike to me (he has plenty of his own).  Originally, I was going to get a road bike, as I ride a Giant Sedona (which I like but thought I might want to go faster until Trout had a horrible wreck the end of October and broke a collarbone and left a good portion of his face on the asphalt).

We had planned on going to Holland next summer and doing bike and barge trip.  The trip looks wonderful but seemed geared to "old people," which we are not (at least not mentally).  I want to have a grand adventure that's tough; I want to be the fearless woman my husband fell in love with when I was 20.  I said let's do an adventure on mountain bikes out West--except I don't have a mountain bike and never really wanted one or so I thought. We contacted REI and asked if we could change the road bike to a mountain bike (we had not picked it up yet).  They said sure.

I decided to get the Novara Ponderosa, a beautiful orange and black hard tail.  Trout said the components were great; it's one of REI's top of the line bikes.  We made a 10 hour trip Saturday to pick it up, and I anxiously awaited my first ride on Sunday.

She kicked my ass.  A mountain bike is a whole different kettle of fish when compared to my comfort bike. When I stop pedalling, it rolls quite quickly to a stop.  I liked a lot of things about her, though; she went up hill better than my other bike, the shifters are cool, the disc brakes are crazy, and the ride is sweet.  I hope she doesn't kill me.

North Dakota's Maah Daah Hey Trail watch out!

When I saw Mayor Naglin on CNN giving the powers-that-be hell, I said right on.  I would have thrown a few mother fuckers in the with god damns.  The man was frustrated and heartbroken as he watched the people of his city suffer and die.  I agreed with every god damned thing he said.

Today, my mother told me that the preacher (preacher in Appalachia means No Education of any Kind but had the "calling") at my brother's church went on and on about New Orlean's mayor taking the Lord's name in vain.  

Jesus Christ.

Trout called this morning, and he had hooked up with MEMA (Mississippi Emergency Management) and was on his way to a shelter in Biloxi.  He called from Laurel, MS and said the damage was widespread--devastation, no electricity, no anything.  He'll call when he can, but I don't imagine that'll be much, as he was already having trouble finding cell phone reception. 

Ironically, the price of gas in Mississippi has not gone through the roof the way it has here in western NC.  There, in the midst of destruction and no gas, no one seems to be gouging the public--that's nice.

I can't believe I haven't updated this journal since the final day of the Tour de France.  A lot and not much have happened since.

Bele Chere was fabulous this year--saw some great bands.  Tinsley Ellis rocked the house on Friday and was a tough act to follow for me.  We saw Drive By Truckers and Bonerama (great horn band from NOLA) on Saturday.  The fact that they charged for one stage on Saturday sucked and most of us festival veterans boycotted that show--boy, we showed them!

The first weekend in August Trout, Becky, and I went down to Panama City to scallop with Trout's family.  It rained for 2 days--for the first time we've visited in years.  Becky and I decided the heck with scalloping and headed for a beach in Gulf County with Cricket (our Jack Russell) on sunny Sunday.  It's the only beach we know of in the panhandle to allow dogs.  She loved it, and Becky and I soaked up the rays.

Trout took me to Heintooga in the Great Smoky Mountains Nat'l Park, and we biked down from the highest campground to Cherokee on a one way dirt road--it was great, and I finally broke the 1,000 mile mark on my odometer.  I also wore out my brakes on the 17 mile descent--it was beautiful and cool in the shade of the park.  We had to cross the headwaters of the Oconluftee River.  The water was deceptively deep and the gravel was fist sized--glad I didn't wreck.

I have been a complete slug as far as biking and fitness, since the first of July.  It's been so hot and we've had so much rain.  Of course, I recognize that these are both excuses; I really do plan to become that svelte model lurking inside me.  The last few mornings have been cool, so I'm getting inspired again.  Wish me luck.

Trout left this morning for Mississippi to volunteer his services in any capacity.  He's an RN but brought his boots, brush gloves, and a hammer in order to help in any way needed.  He's planning to be gone for at least a week and 2 at the most.  I'll miss him but am glad he can help--the hospital has agreed to cover his normal pay without using his PTO, which is pretty cool of them.  The other nurse who was going to go with him had to cancel; in the end, he left alone.  He'll be fine; he's a good soul.  He remembers Camille and its devastation and just felt moved to help.

School started on August 25.  I've 2 great classes (Eng 12 and Eng 10) and 1 challenging class.  It's a class of 29 freshmen and 20 of them are boys.  It's also an inclusion class (thanks No Child Left Behind), which means a number of the students have some type of problem;  I have a number of kids with serious learning disabilities in reading and 3 boys who are BED (Behaviorally and Emotionally Disabled).  So far they are pretty sweet but are a wiggly, giggly, bunch of kids in desperate need of someone's love.  One of them beat himself up on Friday with a padlock but had made up a story about being attacked by an unknown assailant--that's about the saddest student I've run across.  He hit himself hard enough in the face to raise welts and his cheekbone looked awful.  How awful must his life be to need that kind of attention--pretty awful I found out later. They make me cry.

Total bike miles   1024

Ahh!  Lance wins the time trial and his first stage win this year.  He was magnificent today.

If Discovery brings Vinokourov over, I'll forsake them forever.

While Matt and Eli were up, we also had two cross country cyclists stay a night with us.  We hooked up with them through the warm showers list.  Jeremy and Paul were fabulous guests in the old tradition--they kept us entertained with lots of good stories.  They were nearing the end of their California to Charleston, SC ride.  We've since heard from Paul and they happily dipped their tires in the Atlantic a day or two earlier than anticipated.  We had a busy week with Trout working, running to Duke, entertaining them all, the Tour, Tsali, rafting, and just having fun.

Well, the last two times I've ridden my bike I've left from the house on it, which means I have to climb the heartless wench on my return.  I rode up the hill the whole way both times--no pushing.  Of course, I did have to stop twice for a couple of minutes to allow my heart to climb out of my throat and mouth and back into my chest where it belongs.  


July 13's miles         11.2
Today's miles           13
MTD                     77

I asked Trout about my knee pain last night, and he was sure that standing and pedaling uphill was causing stress on my knees.  I shifted to lower gears and stayed in the saddle today and feel much better.

We're keeping an eye on Hurricane Dennis; our ground is saturated and we don't need any rain from this storm.  It looks like it's tracking to our west so maybe we won't be deluged.

Greenway today.

Today             18.2
MTD               53
Total odometer    917  (my odometer had 88 miles on it on Mar 25--that's 829 
                        miles in a little less than 3.5 months--I can't believe
                        it)

My feet sometimes bother me when I've been on the bike for a while--my toes go numb; however, I had a cramp in the "palm" of my foot from almost the moment I started pedaling today.  I got off and tried to stretch it after 11 miles but that didn't help.  My knees have also been bothering me since I started doing hills out of the saddle and standing.  I wonder if standing and pedaling puts my knees in some kind of distress?  I'll have to ask Trout.

Matt and Eli are here for a visit; we hope to get them to Tsali next week, if Hurricane Dennis stays to the west of us!

July 2     18.8 
July 9     16
MTD        34.8

I haven't updated in quite a while--just laziness.  

We had a great time on GOBA and met lots of fun people.  I think I did just fine with the exception of one day that sported a 15-20 mph headwind; it was very demoralizing.  I'm looking for more rides to do!


GOBA            264  miles
June total      405  (cool)

Now, this is nice.  The last online quiz I took said that I was Kip from "Napolean Dynamite."  This is much better.

I am The Sun

In the tarot the Sun symbolizes vitality and splendor. The Sun is definitely not a meek and retiring card. You have total confidence in yourself. You are not cocky, but profoundly sure of your power. You have unlimited energy and glow with health. You have a greatness about you and stand out brilliantly. Finally, you see and understand all that is happening within your sphere. When you see this card, know that you will be successful at all you undertake. Now is the time to let your light shine.

I rode the greenway with Trout this morning.  We rode the bikes from the house (a first for me) and had a really nice ride.  We, however, live on the bitch from hell street--long, long uphill.  I sucked.

We leave for GOBA on Friday--I'm excited and hope I'm up for it.


Today     28
June     141
Odo      600

Trout and I went to the greenway this morning.  He thought it would be a good time to do "training."  It was fun; he had me pedaling at 16mph for a good bit.  It wiped me out.  I did go up the long hill at the end rather than do that one--pretty proud of myself.

Today      19.8
June       89.8

Trout took me to ride the river road today; I had an infamous spill there over a month ago and haven't been back.  I discovered today that I am a stronger and more confident rider--I didn't have to stop at all for a breather and I loved it.  Yeah me!!!

Trout fixed my bike up in preparation for GOBA (2 weeks).  He installed a mirror, a rear rack, and a handlebar bag.  Cool.  It rode fine.

I hit my highest speed ever--30.2 mph.


Today     10.4
June      70
Odometer  508 (yippee)

Wow, today was a scorcher.  I needed to do lots of household chores this morning so decided to wait until this afternoon to ride.  Big mistake--it was humid and hot--everything summer in the South is supposed to be!  I waited until 4pm, and around 5pm, the heat broke but the wind kicked up.  There were lots of kids and parents on bikes today.  The kids always say hi but are dangerous as they'll steer right into my path while smiling and greeting me.

Today's miles    20.3
Month totals     59.6

I was a bum this morning and after Trout left for work (6am), I went back to sleep and woke up when the phone rang at 11am.  Geez.  I didn't sleep well all week and guess I was catching up on some sleep time.

I decided to wait until late afternoon to ride as it was mercilessly hot--the first really warm day we've had.  I rode for two hours and averaged 11.8 miles an hour--not too bad.  I'm going to try to go for broke tomorrow morning--haven't decided what that means yet!

Today      22.5
June       39.3

It's been busy at school this week.  The superintendent didn't get the diplomas signed in timely manner, and I had to go rattle his tree yesterday about getting them finished and to me--hey, graduation is in 2 days but he didn't seem too worried.  Of course, it will be my ass the parents chew up if something goes wrong on the day of their darlings' graduation.  The diploma people were also concerned that the diploma covers might not make it to us in time.  Well, that would suck; what would we give little Mary Lou and Billy as they crossed the stage?  

The covers arrived and I wasn't going to check them because they've always been in alphabetical order in the past; however, one of my cohorts said, "Oh, we'd better be sure they're all there."  They were all there, but they were in no order of any kind!  How can that be?  They're printed in alphabetical order, so how do they not get in the boxes in the same manner?  But what the hell!  Everything is ready and loaded in the Jeep; it always goes well but the anxiety still creeps in.  I just want it to be perfect for the kids--many of whom I'll truly miss.

I rode the greenway after school and it felt good.  I must do this every day---GOBA awaits.

Today's miles      16.8
Odometer total    454.0

My mileage this month stinks.  I allowed busyness/craziness of graduation to interfere with my riding.  I didn't get up off the couch after many long days; I feel so much better physically, emotionally, and even spiritually during and after a ride--I must remember this and stop being a lazy bum.

Only 18 days until GOBA.

May total 163.4

Trout took me to Andrews yesterday to ride the Valley Loop, which winds along the river.  It turned into a beautiful day shortly after we arrived.  The ride was relatively easy (or should have been) and we did about 12 miles an hour.

We went to John deVille's end of the end year party last night.  I only had two drinks but feel like hell today.  I really wish we had gone on that moonlight hike up on Whiteside--what fun.


Today       15
May miles  163.4 (this sucks--I should have way more--lazy)
YTD        344.2
Odo        437.6

I left school early and Trout took me to the infamous Road to Nowhere for an afternoon ride.  The weather was gorgeous--very warm in the sun but a cool breeze was blowing.  

It was the hardest ride yet for me.  We rode for 11 miles, and I swear, half of them were uphill (long Smoky Mtn uphills).  I wasn't fast but I made it up them.  I'd to stop pretty often for a minute rest break for my legs, and I tried to keep the whining to a minimum.  The downhills were fast and scary; Trout never touched his brakes, but I used mine to slow my pace--I wish my trip computer was still working, as I'm sure it'll be awhile before I go that fast again.  All in all, it was a very good day.

Today       11 miles
May        148.4
YTD        329.2
ODO        422.6

I've been incredibly exhausted this past week.  The end of the school is always tiring, but I can't even motivate myself to do anything but collapse in the afternoon.  Our students are finished on Wednesday, so I've only a few more days of everyone being tired of everything.

My seniors kicked butt on their senior project speeches.  All 12 made an A; the best class ever.  I'm really proud of them and will miss them greatly.  My freshmen are just ready to get it over with, and my Humanities class can't wait to finish "Taming of the Shrew" (for a number of reasons).

I didn't ride all week; I was a bum.  But I did get out yesterday (14 miles) and today (18 miles) and am adding those totals as today's total.

Today's miles     31
May              137.4
YTD              318.2
Odo              411.6

We're having Becky's birthday dinner today; she turns 20 tomorrow.  Trout's going to grill a couple of steaks, and I'll do the sides--salad, potatoes, and corn on the cob.  Should be yummy.

I rode 14 miles on the greenway yesterday and 21 today.  The last 7 were wet but for half of that there was a great tail wind.

5-14     14 miles
Today    21 miles
May     106.4 
YTD     287.2
Odomtr  380.6

We staged our Awards' Day for the seniors.  It went well, and now I can relax until Senior Projects next week and then graduation on June 3!  The kids were great and we zipped right through rehearsal.

I went to the greenway and rode for a little over an hour.  It was hot and the air quality was awful.  They're warning us that this year will be the worst on record, as we've already had more dangerous ozone levels than in any previous 12 month period and it's only the middle of May.


Today's miles   16
May miles       71.4
YTD            252.2
Odometer       345.6

The best news is that Trout is home.  He and Nimble Nate arrived yesterday--10 days was a long time.  They had a good trip, despite some rainy days. Now that he's home, I should get back to eating healthier meals.  I hate to cook for just me and the kids (now back from college for the summer) aren't overly fond of our new diets (lots of veggies and little meat).  I made a pretty good veggie teriyaki thing for supper.  Trout and I went to the greenway and did a short ride after dinner and then splurged on a small DQ swirl cone each.  Yum.

Today       9.1
May miles   55.4
Year       236.2
Odometer   329.6

The importance of wind in my life is bizarre.  I never noticed wind before, unless it was blowing over trees in my front yard.  But now that I'm riding a bicycle I notice wind all the time and hate it quite often.  Today, the only ripples on the Little Tennessee were rings from jumping fish, so the riding was fantastic.  

I'm much more confident on the bike; I cross the 4 lanes of traffic with hardly a worry (I still wait for it to be completely safe!).  And I don't brake quite as much on familiar downhills; I wish I still had my trip computer so I could see just how fast I took the downhill at the end of the greenway today.

Trout has called every night and sounds like he's enjoying himself.  I miss him when he's not here--there's no one to make me laugh.

Today's miles    16.1
May miles        46.3
Year            227.1
Total Odometer  320.5

I felt better this morning but had no voice.  I squeaked and squawked my way through school today.  The kids love it; I sound like a crow.

No exercise and I miss Trout like crazy.

I woke up this morning and felt like a truck had run over my head.  I hate getting a cold in the spring; plus my allergies don't help me feel better this time of year.

No exercise.

Wow, I rode my bike 30.2 miles this morning.  It was cool and windy this morning.  Actually, it was very windy and almost killed me.  It was blowing so hard at the Sulli Marsh end that I had to drop it into 2.  It sucked but I did it.  Yeah for me.

Holly and her girlfriends are coming here tonight to watch "Desperate Housewives."  I don't watch it, but with Trout out of town, I'm looking forward to a girls' night.  I'm going to make nachos and chocolate chip cookies; we should have fun.


Miles today    30.2
May miles      30.2
Year          211. (go me)

It rained like crazy this morning.  I turned on the Weather Channel to check out the weather in the Florida panhandle; it looked grim--heavy rain, thunderstorms, and tornado watches.  Trout called around 3pm to say that they'd been holed up at a BP station for a couple of hours, hoping to wait the heaviest rain out.  They plan to camp at Falling Waters tonight; we spent a night there on our honeymoon (22 years ago).  He'll have fun no matter the weather.

I cut the glass for a stained glass panel for a friend's kitchen cabinet.  She wanted colors that I'm not overly fond of but what the heck.  I haven't ground the edges yet, but I think she'll love it.  It's a abstract panel of overlapping circles.  It looks vaguely like planets.  I like its funkiness.

I headed over to the greenway at 3:30 and hadn't been riding for 5 minutes when my trip computer fell off.  Unfortunately, it was while I was crossing the Little Tennessee bridge, and I heard it crunch under the wheels of a big F250.  Damn.  I really hated not knowing my speed.  I doubled the route I took on Wednesday, so I know the mileage.  I'll have to see if Smoky Mountain Bicycles can fix me up.

Today's miles    18.2
April miles     145.9
Year            180.8

My God, headwinds suck.  I can't imagine having to ride all day in them.  I went to the greenway for my first ride in a week this afternoon.  I felt strong as hell and was booking right along in a bigger gear than I usually ride in and thought, "Hey, maybe I needed a week off the bike to get stronger."  Okay, that thinking is obviously flawed.  At that point, I had a tailwind--duh.  I did ride up both hills that have been vexing me--with a stop at the top of both to slow my heart rate.

On the way back, it sucked.  Sand was blowing in my eyes (with sunglasses on), it started to rain, and I had to drop way down in gears to keep up an 11 mph pace.  I was frozen when I got to the Jeep and decided to be a complete wimp and only do 9.1 miles.  This weekend I'm vowing to have a 30 mile day.

Trout leaves in the morning for his Destin to St. Augustine ride.  I'll miss him.

Today         9.1
April miles 127.7
Year        162.6

We almost headed home this morning, as it was freakin' cold when we got out of the tent (30 degrees with high wind).  We were warm and slept soundly through the night while the wind howled and rattled all around us.  Something kept creaking in the wind; I've decided it must have been a tree.  It was too cold to do anything but break camp and head out for breakfast.  We decided to just go home, as we'd had it with standing in the cold and wind.

We went to the Huddle House and bought the local paper.  I read that the cyclists would be signing autographs before the start and was game to get my Tour poster signed.  It really didn't matter who signed it; I wanted to be up close with the cyclists.  We warmed up and decided we were game for another day of tour watching and headed out to watch the boys.

We ended up not standing in the optimum place behind the barricades for autographs.  One needs to stand in the "rider sign in" line, because they have to walk right by you, but, of course, that area was full to capacity (next year we'll know better).  Trout noticed that lots of people on the other side of the barricade had no credentials and urged me to go around.  

I walked up to the front of the line where the riders rolled in and was standing there when a guy next to me (with credentials) handed a camera to a woman and asked her to take his picture with Saul.  Saul Raisin is a 21 year old local boy (from Dalton, Ga--local enough) who rides professionally with the French team Credit Agricole.  OMG!  So I decided to stay put; when Trout came over and asked what I was up to, I said, "This nice lady is going to take a picture of Saul and I'm hoping he'll sign my poster."  She then said, "I'm his mom, actually."  Saul is now my new favorite.  He was sweet and kind, and because his signature was messy, he drew a smiley face.  One of his team mates, Mads Kaggestad, also signed.  I then headed off, at Trout's urging, to get Geoff Kabush's of Jittery Joe's.  I was standing directly next to Floyd Landis, waiting patiently, when he apologized to us all and headed off to the starting area.  What a great time.  We saw Bobby Julich, Levi Leipheimer, and the Discovery Team.  I'm a groupie; I hope a worthy,riding groupie next year.

No exercise, but who the hell cares--I was at the Tour de Georgia.

I left school at 11:30 today; I love to lay-out as much as the kids.  We headed over to Trackrock Campground amid the worse thunder/rain storm we've seen since last fall.  We were able to set up camp without any rain--thank goodness, setting up a tent in the rain sucks. 

We went to a little seafood restaurant and had the buffet (very bad weekend for my diet).  The fried oysters and salmon were delicious, and we hit DQ for a twist cone before heading back to the campground.

Tomorrow the ascent on Brasstown Bald and Lance "Go Baby Go" Armstrong in the Tour de Georgia.

No exercise (again).

Holly and Becky both came for supper today.  Becky wanted tacos; Holly doesn't eat beef; we had turkey tacos.  They were delicious.  It was good to have the girls home and to eat like a family.  We don't get to do it very often now that they're off and in college.

No exercise today.

I went to the greenway by myself after school and rode.  They have a new section open, including a gravel hill I was never able to ride up.  It is now paved and I rode up it in my granny gear--but I made it to the top.  Going down the other side, I hit 26 miles an hour, my fastest ever.  It was scary but felt great.  

Immediately after the downhill, there is a switchback uphill.  I only made it three-quarters of the way up before I had to stop.  A guy on a mountain bike sailed by me exclaiming, "Wow, these hills are killers!"  To which I replied, "If it kills me, just kick me out of the way."  It was a good aerobic workout!  I'm going to keep at the damn thing until I get up it.

School was good; my classes are wonderful, and I haven't had a tiring/bad day all semester.  Life at the trout pond is good.

Miles today 16.8
April miles 118.6 (corrected mileage)
Year miles  153.5

I didn't do anything yesterday; my legs were tired after our ride on Sunday.  I waited for Trout to come home from the doctor (his foot is still broken), and we went to the greenway for a short ride.  Another beautiful day; the students are beginning to skip to sunbathe and go to the lake (although they all said the water was still too cold, but they all went in over the weekend).  

A new portion of the greenway has been opened and it has killer hills!  It'll be a good addition to my workout and for GOBA.

Trout made killer broiled/stuffed tomatoes and corn cakes for dinner.  

Miles today  6.6
April miles  101.9

The National Honor Society Induction for my high school was today and I'm the group sponsor; it went well; although a number of students were out of town on a Military History field trip to Charleston, SC.  But it was over quickly and Trout took me out for a ride.  

We rode the Old River Road in Nantahala.  It is now a Forest Service road, so it was well maintained for dirt.  Most of it was slightly uphill (if you read Trout's journal, he'll say flat) and a very small part had me panting like a freight train.  But I kept pedaling; I don't think I could have done it without stopping just a week ago.

We stopped at the Nantahala Outdoor Center for a quick supper of cheeseburgers and fries--very good.  It blows my diet, but I've been really good.  And to top off the evening, Trout made a blueberry cobbler (my fav) with our wild blueberries from last summer.

Miles today 12 
April miles 95.3

It was gorgeous today.  We had a cold night with a chilly morning.  We worked in the yard until early afternoon, and Trout planted some tomatoes and peppers; the weatherman is now saying we may get frost tonight, so we'll have to cover them.

Trout went on a long road ride and I went to the greenway.  It was a perfect day to be outside and on a bike.  I'm beginning to love it.  

Miles today     15.3
April miles     83.5

I did really well with food today; I had a banana for a mid-morning snack and didn't snack the rest of the day.  Trout made a delicious veggie teriyaki stir fry for dinner.  It was beautiful today--spring is sprung.  The dogwoods are in bloom and our yard, from the deck, is a lagoon of blossoms.

Pilates for 40 minutes (I can do the sit-ups a bit better now--still not great).

I (and over 100 other Macon County school employees) attended a hypnosis session for weight loss last night.  I was psyched because I feel like I'm finally getting it together about my weight and health.  I fully intended to allow this to work.  

The hypnosis was interesting.  I have never felt quite so relaxed yet understood everything going on around me--actually I was afraid that I was too conscious.  It took about 45 minutes (after a 30 minute introductory session).  The hypnotist focused our attention on "greasy, fatty foods," "sugary sweet foods," "drinking more water," and "exercise."  

I came home and we ordered Mexican.  I love chips and salsa, yet they were a non issue for me.  I looked at them but didn't really want one--AND DIDN'T EAT ANY.  I can't explain it.  I did eat the burrito and shouldn't have eaten the whole thing, but the more I think about those chips, I'm stumped.  The weirdest thing is that when I told one of my co-workers who also attended, she almost fainted.  They had gone out to eat Mexican, too, and she wasn't interested in the chips either and didn't eat any.  Weird.  But hey, if it helps, I'm all for it.

Before the seminar, I rode 11.8 miles on the greenway in 61 minutes.

Miles today 11.8
April total 68.2
It's rained all day so no riding.  I could have done Tae-Bo or pilates, but that would spoil my laziest person on earth image.
Did no exercise today--very bad, and I already feel guilty and like a bum.  I could have done some.

I worked for about 2 hours this morning, getting papers graded and entered in the computer.  I then went out to Cullasaja Center for the Arts (my friends Jan and Jim's newest venture) to have a print framed for my in-laws.  I know more about framing than I ever desired, but it should be quite attractive.

Trout and I went to the greenway for a ride late this afternoon.  We did 17 miles in 83 minutes (not too great for Trout but pretty good for me).  I feel exhausted and energized at the same time.  A great day.

Miles today       17 greenway
Miles this month  56.4

I was so disgusted with myself at my performance on my bike yesterday that I fixed us breakfast and headed to the greenway.  The only people out and about on a Sunday morning in the Bible Belt were runners and a solitary dog walker.  The morning was beautiful and I recorded my best time yet.  12.8 miles an hour (average).  I feel much better about it today.  

After my ride, I hit the stained glass class and bought 2 pieces of art glass for a project for a friend (a kitchen cupboard door).  Both pieces are blues and purples; I can't wait to get to work on it.  I'll have to post a picture to my glass community.

We went for a ride to Standing Indian and had a picnic at Hurricane Creek.  Cricket rummaged for food at the campsite and came up with white bread crusts and a piece of cheese.

Miles today       12  greenway
Miles this month  39.4

I got up early and went to help Tiffani with her car show.  She's in my Eng 12 Honors class and decided to plan and conduct a car show.  There were some beautiful cars--a total of 48 came, but I was most impressed with how well it ran.  Tiffani put a lot of man hours into organization and it showed.  It was a charity event for the Lions Club vision program (which provided eye surgery for her when she was a child), and she raised $1362.00.  I'm very proud of her and my other 6-8 students who came out as volunteers today.

Trout and I went riding this afternoon to the Cullasaja River Road.  Part of it is dirt and in a split second I was in the wet, muddy ditch and then on the ground.  I didn't get hurt, but the rest of the ride felt like I was pedaling in pea soup.  I don't know if it was a combo of today's fall and Thursday's fall down the stairs, but I could barely move my legs.  I'm quite disappointed with myself and know Trout wanted to go further the the 6 miles I managed.  I'm going out in the morning and try to make up for it.

Well, I didn't get to excerise at all today.  I fell down our exterior flight of stairs this morning and did a number on my left shin.  I fell down these same stairs around 7 years ago, so I've been very careful on them since then.  Maybe tomorrow.
